title: 105_hr715
content: The Act may be cited as the "Accuracy in Campus Crime Reporting Act of 1997" and refers to amendments or repeals made to the Higher Education Act of 1965. It includes provisions for the disclosure of crimes reported and daily crime logs. The "Accuracy in Campus Crime Reporting Act of 1997" amends Section 485(f)(1)(F) of the Higher Education Act of 1965. It updates the reporting requirements for campus security and law enforcement officials regarding crimes such as homicide, sex offenses, robbery, assault, burglary, and larceny. The "Accuracy in Campus Crime Reporting Act of 1997" expands reporting requirements to include incidents of burglary, larceny, motor vehicle theft, arson, simple assault, and vandalism. Institutions must annually submit statistics to the Secretary for reporting to relevant committees. The "Accuracy in Campus Crime Reporting Act of 1997" mandates that institutions report crime statistics to the House of Representatives, Senate Committee on Labor and Human Resources, and the public. Statistics must adhere to Department of Justice standards and be certified for accuracy. Crime logs are also required to be maintained. Each institution participating in programs under this title must maintain a daily crime log that records all reported crimes in chronological order, including details like nature, date, time, location, disposition of complaints, citations issued, and charges made. Each institution must maintain a daily crime log with details of reported crimes, including names, addresses, and charges of persons arrested. The log may also identify victims, witnesses, or suspects not arrested. Entries must be open to public inspection within 24 hours, unless disclosure is prohibited by law. Release of information may be delayed if it jeopardizes an ongoing investigation or individual safety. The institution must maintain a daily crime log with details of reported crimes, including names, addresses, and charges of persons arrested. Information may be withheld if it jeopardizes an investigation, individual safety, or evidence preservation. Exceptions to reporting provisions should be narrow, with only legally protected information kept confidential. Reports can be disseminated electronically to reach the campus population promptly. Victims' rights are also protected under the law. The institution of higher education must develop and distribute a statement of policy regarding on-campus disciplinary practices for alleged infractions of the institution's code of conduct or other policies related to criminal acts. This includes procedures to be followed once a crime has occurred. The institution of higher education must have a policy regarding on-campus disciplinary practices for alleged infractions, including procedures after a crime has occurred. The policy should ensure that all students are informed of their options to notify law enforcement, both the accuser and accused have equal rights during disciplinary proceedings, and outcomes are disclosed. Disciplinary proceedings for criminal misconduct must be open, and records should be accessible. The amendments made by this section regarding the accessibility of records for criminal misconduct proceedings will take effect on January 1, 1998. SEC. 3. EXEMPTION OF ALLEGATIONS OF CRIMINAL ACTIVITY FROM EDUCATION RECORDS DEFINITION. Amendment to the General Education Provisions Act exempts records of individuals accused of criminal activity while attending an educational institution from being classified as education records. The curr_chunk discusses the details related to disciplinary proceedings resulting from alleged misconduct, including charges, findings, sanctions, and case status. The curr_chunk discusses amendments to sanctions related to criminal misconduct and reporting requirements under the Higher Education Act of 1965, effective September 1, 1998. The curr_chunk discusses enforcement related to the Higher Education Act of 1965. Enforcement and retaliation measures are outlined in amendments to the Higher Education Act of 1965. Noncompliance by institutions of higher education will result in termination of assistance or other specified orders by the Secretary. Additionally, any form of intimidation, threats, coercion, or discrimination against individuals is prohibited. The Higher Education Act of 1965 amendments prohibit intimidation, threats, coercion, or discrimination against individuals interfering with the implementation of the provisions. Program participation agreements must include comprehensive and accurate policies and crime statistics. Effective date for these amendments is September 1, 1998.
